key_title: Key to the species of Adiantum

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the families of ferns and allied plants
Key to the genera of Pteridaceae

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta)
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1994). Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta). In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Pinnules with long (1 mm or more), fine stalks attached near centre of wedge-shaped base
Pinnules with short (usually less than 1 mm) stalks at one corner of approximately rhomboid pinnules
Sori 1–4 per pinnule, kidney-shaped, outer margin deeply concave
Sori 3–7 per pinnule, oblong, with outer margin flat or slightly concave (if sori 3–7 per pinnule and kidney-shaped, and pinnules deeply dissected between sori, see notes under A. aethiopicum)
Rhizome short; fronds tufted, less than 45 cm tall; sori in deep notches between lobes
Rhizome long; fronds well-separated, more than 45 cm tall; sori in shallow hollows of lobes (4–8 per pinnule)
Fronds soft; pinnules with numerous small, stiff reddish-brown hairs on under-surface; rachises glabrous; sori 5–10 per pinnule
Fronds relatively harsh; pinnules and rachises with numerous soft white hairs on undersurface; sori mostly more than 10 per pinnule
Pinnules dark green, not noticeably paler beneath; abaxial pinnule surfaces with sparse to dense pale setose hairs
Pinnules blue-green, paler beneath; abaxial pinnule surfaces with crowded pale lax hairs
